fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A quotient object x/r is the coequalizer of a congruence r\xrightarrow {r_1,r_2} x.

The rational numbers \mathbb {Q} are the quotient of the product \mathbb {Z}\times \mathbb {Z}\setminus 0 of the integers with the integers without zero by the relation (p, q)\sim (p', q')\text { iff } pq' = qp'.

fr:title.text: Construction of the localization of a category

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Construction of the localization of a category

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The localization C_S of a category C at S is exhibited by the following (not necessarily small) construction:

fr:ul.fr:li: the objects of C_S are those of C;

a morphism in C_S is a zig-zag of morphisms in C, where the "rightward" maps consist only of those in S, modulo the relations generated by composition, the identities, and the equations x\xrightarrow {s}y\xleftarrow {s}x \sim 1_x and y\xleftarrow {s}x\xrightarrow {s} y \sim 1_y whenever s\in S.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The embedding Q sends x\xrightarrow {f} y to the "singleton" zig-zag x\xrightarrow {f} y, and inverts S by construction. To exhibit the universal property, suppose C\xrightarrow {F} D is given and inverts S. Then define F_S on a zig-zag by mapping it over the zig-zag and composing in D. The diagram commutes on the nose (note in particular that the relations on C_S don't break this, because they hold in D as well; this is essentially the universal property of the quotient), so it remains to show the uniqueness property. But the functor must act appropriately on the inclusion and preserve composites, so this is immediate.

The regular coimage of a map x\xrightarrow {f} y is always a quotient, which we write x/\ker f. The inuition is that the kernel pair is (in Set-like settings) like the set of pairs of elements of x which agree in y, and so the coequalizer is like the set of nonempty fibers of f.
Let N\unlhd G. Then the quotient group G/N is the quotient object of the induced congruence; explicitly, it is the set of cosets of N in G with the operation (gN)(hN) = (gh)N.

To show that this defines a group, note that the induced equivalence relation is a congruence, hence compatible with the group multiplication, so that the multiplication is well-defined. The group axioms are direct from those of G.

To exhibit the universal property, let G\xrightarrow {f} H be any homomorphism which is constant on equivalence classes. Since G/N is also the quotient set, It suffices to show that the induced set-function \tilde {f} is a homomorphism: \tilde {f}(ghN) = f(gh) = f(g)f(h) = \tilde {f}(g)\tilde {f}(h).
The quotient of a set X by an equivalence relation \sim is the set of equivalence classes of \sim , i.e. \{\{x: x\sim x_0\}: x_0\in X\}.

fr:title.text: Quotient object › universal property of quotients

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Quotient object › universal property of quotients

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: An internal relation r\xhookrightarrow {(r_1, r_2)} x^2 is an equivalence relation or congruence if it is:

fr:ul.fr:li: reflexive, i.e. there is a map x\xrightarrow {s} r which is a section of both r_1 and r_2;
symmetric, i.e. there is a map r\xrightarrow {\sigma } r which exchanges r_1 and r_2;

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A coequalizer is a colimit of a diagram of shape \bullet \rightrightarrows \bullet .
